blog.title: andi mack trash
blog.description:

summary: Why do you think TJ treated Buffy badly at the beginning?
question: Why do you think TJ treated Buffy badly at the beginning?
answer:
Based on their initial interactions in “Friends Like These” and the basketball game in “The Snorpion”, it’s made pretty clear that TJ is overcompensating because he doesn’t want to be beaten/upstaged by a girl. 

If you want a more psychological breakdown, my best theory would be something along these lines: Prior to ever meeting Buffy, TJ has created this persona at school in which he is the tough guy, and people buy into it. When you are treated like you’re famous, or infamous, it goes to your head and you play it up more and more. So by that point in time, he is already convinced he is untouchable and he plays up that persona even more when his friends from the basketball team are around. 

I am also willing to bet that by this point, he has internally latched onto this idea that basketball is the thing he is good at. Like he may struggle in school and no tutor can handle him and he may have a lot of “stuff”, but as long as he is still a top athlete he has something going for him, that kind of thing. So he overcompensates to protect that idea for himself. 

What’s interesting is when we see him later in “The Snorpion”, where he and Buffy talk outside of the record shop… when she first approaches him, he isn’t actually mean to her. He seems to be caught off guard, but he says hey and then listens to what she has to say. Implying that much of the jerk-vibes he let off in their earlier scenes together were because his hype men were around. She asks what she can do to make him not hate her, and he answers honestly. He wanted her to switch to a girls’ team, which only reinforces the idea that he is overcompensating because he doesn’t want her to upstage him. This could be based in the insecurities he has about how other people view him, but also how he views himself. 

Throughout the learning disability storyline, I think he still struggles with caring what other people think about him - but I think the struggle for him is more how he thinks about himself. Like when he starts to feel insecure, he seems to just shut down. When he runs out on Buffy before going to the swing set, I don’t think he actually cared whether or not she thought he was stupid, he just didn’t want to feel stupid. And usually, being around Buffy made him feel poorly about himself in general, because she was good in school and sports and friends. He didn’t know how to deal with his own self-loathing around someone like that. 

But I think throughout the rest of season two, there is a shift in which it becomes clear that TJ isn’t being a jerk on purpose. It’s just all he knows how to do. That’s why I don’t really like watering his self-improvement down to being for Cyrus. It’s more than that. As he tries to better himself, there’s a genuine struggle to do so. He didn’t tell the coach that Buffy did his homework to get her in trouble, he did it because he was trying to be honest. But when Buffy accused him of doing it to spite her, when she said that everything he says is a lie, he agrees with her because it’s easier to keep being the bad guy than to keep showing his vulnerability in trying to become a better person. 

From their earliest interactions, in my opinion, you can see that his problem is not with Buffy, but with himself.

summary: I love looking back at TJ and Cyrus and comparing them to where they are now. TJ went from briefly making fun of Cyrus for not...
question: I love looking back at TJ and Cyrus and comparing them to where they are now. TJ went from briefly making fun of Cyrus for not being able to get his own muffin during the cafeteria scene to literally shoving Reed (with quite a lot of force) because he was making fun of Cyrus. Cyrus went from being nervous/scared when he was approached while singing at the swings to standing up for myself in swingset 2.0 and forcing TJ to apologise. Those boys did that to each other and it's beautiful.
answer: Tyrus is the most fleshed out, and most thoughougly developed relationship on the whole show

reblog.comment: Tyrus is the most fleshed out, and most thoughougly developed relationship on the whole show

trail.content_raw: Tyrus is the most fleshed out, and most thoughougly developed relationship on the whole show
trail.content: Tyrus is the most fleshed out, and most thoughougly developed relationship on the whole show

summary: The TJ/Cyrus confession scene isn't going to make sense to casual viewers if there isn't a canon build up to it oved at least a...
question: The TJ/Cyrus confession scene isn't going to make sense to casual viewers if there isn't a canon build up to it oved at least a few episodes beforehand. Like minimum we need a set up like Cyrus taking to Buffy/someone or a hug that plays off his existing conversation about heart beats signalling his crushes.  Squeezing everything into just a few minutes  (with scenes likely cut in editing) really won't be that satisfying to watch
answer: Right. Sometimes I forget to consider the casual audience and how they view things. Cyrus outwardly speaking about his crush on TJ would be pretty important for Tyrus to make sense to a lot of people. Let’s hope Disney followed through

reblog.comment: Right. Sometimes I forget to consider the casual audience and how they view things. Cyrus outwardly speaking about his crush on TJ would be pretty important for Tyrus to make sense to a lot of people. Let’s hope Disney followed through

summary: Theories  on One in a Minyan
title: Theories  on One in a Minyan
body:
For you goyim, a minyan is 10 people which is the number of people necessary to open the torah. 

1 in 10 is that quote we always hear about the ratio of gays to straights. 

It could also just be a joke on one in a million or about someone dying and needing a minyan for shiva (the time of mourning)

idk, just some things to think about

@persongoingfast does this theory hold any water?

summary: Can you explain a Minyan I tried to Google it but I didn't really understand
question: Can you explain a Minyan I tried to Google it but I didn't really understand
answer:
I’m not an expert in this, as I myself am not actually Jewish, but from my understanding - a Minyan is the group of 10 people needed to perform certain religious traditions and services. Traditionally they are all adult (age 13 or older) and they are all men, but modern Judaism can be more lenient about the requirements. Simply-put: It is a tradition that dates back to Israel and is “required” for various religious ceremonies and public prayers.

Hopefully that’s a basic enough explanation and hopefully I’m accurate enough about that. My understanding comes from a few years of self-taught education on the Abrahamic religions, as well as the Jewish media I have consumed, so I really am not too confident. I’m sure it will either be explained in an appropriate context in the show, or Josh will explain it on here for those of you who are confused!

summary: The 6 Times Jonah Almost Kissed Walker, and the 1 Time He Did
body:
The 6 Times Jonah Almost Kissed Walker, and the 1 Time He Did

Part 1: Baby Taters

Word Count: 242

Pairing(s): Wonah

Genre(s): Fluff

Trigger Warning(s): None

———

Jonah and Walker were hanging at The Spoon, laughing over an order of baby taters. Walker pulled out his phone, and started playing a game.

“Feed me baby taters, I can’t lose focus on this level!” Walker says to Jonah, intently staring at the screen.

Jonah awkwardly picks up a baby tater, feeding it to Walker. This goes on for about a minute, Walker playing his game intensely, Jonah feeding him baby taters.

“Ah! Damnit! I just died!” Walker says, upset. He grabs a baby tater, shoving it into his mouth.

“Sorry you lost.”

“It’s whatever. Thanks for feeding me baby taters, that totally helped me stay focused on the game,” Walker said, smiling at Jonah.

“No problem,” Jonah said, blushing.

‘Walker is really cute. I wonder what it would be like to kiss him? NO DON’T THINK LIKE THAT YOU GUYS ARE JUST FRIENDS!’

Jonah quickly pushed the thoughts from his head, though they still lurked in the back of his mind.

Jonah went back to talking with Walker, asking if he could try the game he was playing. Walker said yes, so Jonah started playing. He was really good, and beat the level in only a couple minutes.

“Wha- How- WHEN?” Walker said, dumbfounded.

“Practice, my friend, practice.”

They sat for a few moments in a comfortable silence. Walker was the one to eventually break the silence.

“Hey, you want to come over to my house for a sleepover tonight?”

Taglist:

| @judgemental-llama | @tyrus-is-endgame-fight-me | @a-bittersweet-gal | @wanna-feel-alive |

(Let me know if you want to be added/removed!)
